The SPINDLE chamber floor smells like old coolant and new paperwork.
A dull containment sphere sits in the center, three rotating frames around it—each with maintenance markings that disagree by decade.
Near the approach, a strip of witness-marker tape makes a neat, legal shape on the floor. It does not match any safety standard you recognize. It matches a form.

You take one last look across the floor—the sphere, the lights, the tape that pretends it’s just tape.
Then you head for the stairs down to the observation deck. The hum follows you, consistent as a policy.

You take one last look at the witness perimeter, like it might move when you aren’t watching. It doesn’t.
You head for the stairs down to the observation deck. The hum follows you, consistent as a policy.

You angle back toward the overflow intake concourse.
The chamber stays behind you, quietly maintaining its version of “normal.”

You angle back toward the overflow intake concourse with the tape line fixed in your mind as a procedural edge.
The chamber stays behind you, quietly maintaining its version of “normal.”
